entry.title: [omnibox][ml] stable_sort in RunBatchUrlScoringModelWithStableSearches()
entry.content:
When multiple URL suggestions have been assigned the same ML score, the

RunBatchUrlScoringModelWithStableSearches() function currently works in

such a way as to assign larger traditional scores to those suggestions

which occur earlier in the suggestion list versus those which occur

later in the suggestion list. However, this behavior is only possible

if base::ranges::sort() behaves as a "stable" sorting algorithm. As it

currently stands, this property is technically NOT guaranteed by the

API for this function (whereas it is guaranteed by the

base::ranges::stable_sort() function).



In other words, suppose we start off with `prediction_and_position_heap`

containing the following entries: [{0.017, 0}, {0.017, 1}, {0.017, 2}].

If we applied a non-stable sorting algorithm, while using the first item

of each pair as the sorting key, then it's technically possible for the

elements of this vector to get shuffled around (despite having equal

values for the sorting key). If this were to occur, then the score

redistribution logic used by ML Scoring would start assigning the wrong

traditional scores to the wrong suggestions.



As such, this CL swaps out the use of base::ranges::sort() with

base::ranges::stable_sort() in order to ensure that the resulting code

is guaranteed to work in all cases (i.e. the underlying sorting

algorithm is guaranteed to be "stable" by the C++ standard).



Bug: N/A

Change-Id: Ia9c604122528878396c4dadb6c654871c1009b49

entry.title: Protected Audience: store B&A keys in database 1/2
entry.content:
In an effort to speed up bidding and auction key fetches, store keys in the database as a second caching layer (in addition to the current in-memory cache). This CL is part 1 of 2 of this change and provides the necessary database storage methods. A follow up will connect the new key storage methods up through the caching storage and interest group manager classes, and use them (behind a feature flag) in BiddingAndAuctionServerKeyFetcher.

entry.title: blink: reordering of comparisons in Element::AttributeChanged
entry.content:
My main goal is reducing the cost of this function. Moving

kFocusgroupAttr to AttributeChanged is unlikely to directly help,

but it clears up what I think is some confusing code.



This does the following:

. Moves checking for kSlotAttr later. AFAICT there is no need for

this to be first, and it's uncommon, so better moved later.

. kTabIndex was checked in AttributeChanged() and ParseAttribute(),

as well as handled by HTMLElement::TriggersForAttributeName.

AFAICT the handling in TriggersForAttributeName is unnecessary.

The logic was added here:

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/633915/2/third_party/WebKit/Source/core/html/HTMLElement.cpp

but the code has since changed and no longer is necessary.

. I also removed kFocusgroupAttr handling to AttributeChanged.



I think the split between what belongs in AttributeChanged vs

ParseAttribute is unclear, and we should combine them, but it's

a bit out of scope of this change.

entry.title: [exo] Trigger output activation notifications from wayland::Server
entry.content:
Currently each instance of WaylandDisplayHandler (client-specific

output handle in exo) maintains its own aura shell observation

so that it can notify clients when the output it corresponds to

has been activated.



This CL moves the observation into exo::wayland::Server code and

delegates to the appropriate WaylandDisplayOutput global wrapper

where appropriate.



This CL concludes the centralization of display-related

observations into the Server class. The result is cleaner and easier

to understand code.



Follow up CLs will extract display-output related logic out of

Server and into an independent class responsible for handling

wayland output objects in exo, making new output extensions easier

to implement and support.



Note: Since output activation is now propagated from Server, the

ActiveDisplay unittest has been moved into the aura shell server

tests. This allows correct widget activation => client output event

testing post refactor.

entry.title: Add metrics for spare renderer
entry.content:
Add two metrics:

* BrowserRenderProcessHost.SpareProcessDelayTime

Records the time elapsed from the initiation of the spare process

warm-up to the actual creation of the process.

* BrowserRenderProcessHost.SpareProcessStartupTime

Records the time elapsed from the creation of the spare process to the

point when the process becomes ready. This does not include the

scheduled delay time.

entry.title: Fix browser system media controls not going away.
entry.content:
With #enable-web-app-system-media-controls-win, system media controls

for the browser was not going away when the last tab playing audio was

closed.



Furthermore, with #enable-web-app-system-media-controls-win enabled, when one tab playing audio is closed - the

browser smc was not able to fall back to other tabs playing audio.



This change reworks instanced system media controls to utilize an active

media session controller that follows the active browser sessions while

ignoring web app sessions. This allows the browser to continue to use

an AMSC that follows the active session, thus restoring fallback and

automatic dismissal when browser sessions are closed.



**For security/mojo review**:



These changes are part of this design doc: https://docs.google.com/document/d/12dVKreUCjtZZaUqeh3VxGMsGPMC4POhK/edit



We originally did not anticipate any mojo changes for this feature, but in order to fix the bug outlined in this CL - we needed to make this small change.



The mojo changes do not intend to change any existing structure of information passing - only that services/media_session/audio_focus_manager needs to take different action based on a flag set from content/browser/media/session/media_session_impl.



The purpose of this flag is essentially to mark the media session as for web apps - thus causing it not to be eligible to become the 'active session'. The reason this is desirable is because web app sessions are tracked separately by an "ActiveMediaSessionController" that specifically follows one session and does not follow around an active session.



The user of an "ActiveMediaSessionController" that follows the active session is only the browser - where all tabbed browser media sessions bubble up to one singular concept of "the media the browser is currently playing". Thus needs to change based on what the user interacted with most recently. In other words, we do not want a web apps' media session to show up in the browser's singleton instance when the web app is activated, used or updated.

entry.title: TrayBubble: bubble updates on scale factor change
entry.content:
Currently, tray bubble views are all created with a 'kRect' anchor mode.

This results in bubbles not getting updated when the scale factor

changes even if it is anchored to a tray item, so the placement in the

screen is incorrect.



This CL updates the tray bubble view to use the correct anchor mode,

which automatically observes these changes and updates the anchor rect.

entry.title: controlled frame: Enable the API to be used (with flags) in stable
entry.content:
While here, add some additional info about |AvailabilityCheck()|

describing what it does, how it's called, and more information about

callers and the feature's dependencies.



This change includes additional tests:

1. A parameterized test within an IWA scope that verifies across

all channels that Controlled Frame is available.

2. A parameterized test within a PWA scope that verifies across

all channels that Controlled Frame is not available.



The change includes some fix-ups for our promise-based tests:



- Since "async" functions implicitly return a promise (if not

already returning one), then any return with a non-promise will

get promise-wrapped. Update all of those instances to use resolve

or reject instead so they also use the promise machinery.



- Where a 'FAIL' return was written before, update that to use

'reject' and a 'return'.



Finally, fix some cases where JsReplace() was unnecessary.



Bug: 1233993, b/319655322

entry.title: Introduce span::split_at() and as_writable_byte_span()
entry.content:
Add span::split_at() to help with making it super obvious when writing

to a larger span in multiple operations and ensuring the writes

a) fill the whole span

b) don't overlap by mistake



Add base::as_writable_byte_span() to make a writable uint8_t span

from a range/span. And base::byte_span_from_ref() to simplify

making a byte-span from a single object in one step.



Make base::as_byte_span() and as_writable_byte_span() able to retain

the size of the input at compile time if the input is an array, which

can allow copy_from() and memcpy() inside it to optimize better for

small sizes (when inlining fails).



Bug: 1490484

entry.title: Improve formatting and sorting of Attribution Internals columns
entry.content:
- Numeric columns are right-aligned and use tabular digits for ease of

comparison (screenshots in https://crbug.com/1523252#c2)

- Numeric columns are sorted numerically instead of textually

- Event-level epsilon is formatted to 3 decimal digits for ease of

scanning

- Anchor tags are used for URLs for ease of copy-paste and navigation

- List columns (destinations, dedup keys) are sorted

- List-flattening is replaced by removal of list-item markers, likewise

allowing them to be formatted numerically (screenshots in

https://crbug.com/1523252#c3)

entry.title: `StrictNumeric` in `base::span::first(...)` and `last(...)`: Prep 2/N.
entry.content:
This CL prepares for using `StrictNumeric` (instead of just

`size_t`) as the type of a parameter taken by `base::span::first` and/or

`base::span::last` methods. This is done by tweaking callers of these

methods to ensure that they either:



* Pass a `size_t` value as an argument, or

* Pass size as a compile-time argument (e.g. `some_span.first<123>()`)



This CL also opportunistically performs a similar change for some

callers of `base::span::subspan`.



Bug: 1490484

entry.title: Refactor voice selection menu to its own component using event-based
entry.content:
pattern for voice selection and preview.



This is in preparation of future additions where we'll be adding more

complex logic for voice selection. Having a voice-selection component

keeps read-anything-toolbar TS code cleaner.



The event-based pattern allows us to decouple the voice-selection

component from the read-anything-app component, eliminating the need

for the child component to directly call its parent's functions (via

`this.contentPage.`). Without this, it would have been messy to break

voice selection to its own component, because it would've needed to

call read-anything-toolbar's methods which calls read-anything-app's

methods.



Also, the event based pattern allows us to move away from passing

callbacks to the HTML (via MenuStateItem) and later invoking that

callback from TS.





Bug: 1474951

entry.title: Revert "Ensure SadTab is shown even when previously hidden due to speculative"
entry.content:
This reverts commit f87e77be2eb0e78c980e4cb8bfba130548030c72.



Reason for revert: Causing regressions for BFCache/Prerender and potentially new crashes (see crbug.com/1521450#c7)



Original change's description:

> Ensure SadTab is shown even when previously hidden due to speculative

> frame swap

>

> This change resets the sad tab in sad_tab_helper on RenderFrameCreated,

> to better match the logic that hides it in WebView:

> WebView::RenderFrameHostChanged ->

> WebView::SetUpNewMainFrame ->

> WebView::UpdateCrashedOverlayView // Before RenderFrameHostChanged,

> web_contents()->IsCrashed() gets reset (to false), and this function

> will mark it not-visible as a result.

>

> In SadTabHelper, RenderViewReady may happen after

> PrimaryMainFrameRenderProcessGone, so it isn't a suitable place to

> clear sad_tab_. Subsequent PrimaryMainFrameRenderProcessGone are

> ignored by SadTabHelper, so WebView doesn't get the signal to

> show the crash overlay view again.

>

> This change removes the sad_tab_ in RenderFrameCreated, ensuring we

> show the sad tab if we swap render frames and that one also crashes.

>

> Added a test that fails without the change

>

> Bug: 1502678

> Change-Id: Ice1232cd7f0b9c46d8b591c7126745a54c820f17

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5080430

> Reviewed-by: Charlie Reis

> Commit-Queue: Stefan Smolen

> Reviewed-by: Alex Moshchuk

> Reviewed-by: Peter Kasting

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1236636}

entry.title: [a11y] Only serializing inline-block elements with siblings
entry.content:
We only want to include in the tree if the inline block element

has siblings.

Otherwise we will include nodes that we don't need for anything.

Consider a structure where we have a node 11 descendants, all

which are inline-block and all which have no siblings. For the purposes

of Next/PrevOnLine computation, neither of the descendants provides any

useful information for the computation of these attributes.



If they did have siblings, then they might have NextOnLine/PrevOnLine

elements so we would consider them.



This CL massively helps with a regression that was introduced with

CL:5177314.

Pinpoint: https://pinpoint-dot-chromeperf.appspot.com/job/17e5c1e3ae0000



Bug:1520710.



Change-Id: I5d14f7cfaa638af9698a5b368d6384254e26d1ef

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5238643

Reviewed-by: Aaron Leventhal

entry.title: sensors: Stash virtual sensor readings sent before a sensor is activated
entry.content:
This is a follow-up to the discussion in https://crrev.com/c/5233627,

where it was argued that the current behavior of discarding virtual

sensor updates when the sensor is inactive or not present is not very

intuitive or user-friendly.



Updates were discarded in the following situations but not anymore:

- The virtual sensor was created, but the sensor itself not (e.g. there

has been no call to Sensor.start()).

- The virtual sensor was created, one or more Sensor instances have been

started, activated and they have all been stopped.

- The virtual sensor was created, one or more Sensor instances have been

started but they have not been activated yet.

- The virtual sensor was created, one or more Sensor instances have been

created and started, but the page has become hidden.



In all the cases above, we now stash the reading and try to submit it

once the sensor becomes active again (in //services parlance, that is

when VirtualPlatformSensor::StartSensor() is called). If multiple

updates are sent while the sensor is not active, only the last one will

be used in the delayed update.



To avoid races and out-of-order updates, all calls to

VirtualPlatformSensor::AddReading() are now asynchronous and go through

PostTask().



This change makes it easier to use the Device Orientation API with

WebDriver, as contrary to the Generic Sensors API, all sensor creation,

initialization and suspension is done implicitly via event listeners.

This meant that before this change, one needed to be very careful with

the order of virtual sensor creation, event listener creation, and

submission of reading updates. Specifically, the only reliable way to

add readings and receive them with WebDriver was to:

1. Create virtual sensors

2. Add a dummy device{motion,orientation,orientationabsolute} event

listener

3. Use WebDriver to wait for the virtual sensors to be initialized and

activated

4. Add one or more real event listeners

5. Send an update via WebDriver



With this CL, one only needs to:

1. Create virtual sensors

2. Send an update via WebDriver

3. Add one or more real event listeners

with steps 2 and 3 being interchangeable.



Bug: 1520919, 1506995

Change-Id: Ic560e4db82490f3641984b989a984837cd7316d2

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5245506

Reviewed-by: Reilly Grant

Auto-Submit: Raphael Kubo Da Costa

Commit-Queue: Reilly Grant

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1254071}

entry.title: vt: Snapshot containing block resize skips transition
entry.content:
This CL adds a check for the snapshot containing block (SCB) changing

before capturing new state. We already checked for a changed SCB on each

animation frame, however, this one corresponds to the check that

occurs in the Activate View Transition[1] steps of the spec. This

difference is web-observable since, without this line, the transition

isn't skipped until animation frames are being produced. This means we

don't reject the `ready` promise, as a strict reading of the spec would

imply.



This was also an issue in same-document view transitions (i.e. triggered

by `startViewTransition()`). This CL affects both same- and

cross-document transitions.



[1] https://www.w3.org/TR/css-view-transitions-1/#activate-view-transition:~:text=transitions%20to%20false.-,If%20transition%E2%80%99s%20initial%20snapshot%20containing%20block%20size%20is%20not%20equal%20to%20the%20snapshot%20containing%20block%20size%2C%20then%20skip%20the%20view%20transition%20for%20transition%2C%20and%20return.,-Capture%20the%20new



Bug: 1404957

Change-Id: I6fabee0f7106ba21597fcc576277beb6604dec6b

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5238295

entry.title: Don't use raw_ptr inside a signal handler
entry.content:
Don't use raw_ptr<> inside a signal handler. Raw_ptr assumes the

allocator's internals are in a consistent state and that certain

external invariants are true. A signal handler can run in the middle of

an allocation function when that is not a valid assumption.



Also add a note in the documentation.



Discussion: https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/chromium-dev/c/-uDDljifahk/



BUG=chromium:1490624

Fixed: chromium:1490624

entry.title: Experiment with measuring NextIdleTimeTicks after a delay.
entry.content:
Currently, NextIdleTimeTicks works as follows: It measures the current

TimeTicks the next time the UI thread (in the browser process) becomes

idle. By doing that, it avoids that the following scenario can happen:



A user emits two input events at times t1 and t2, which are processed

at times t1b and t2b on the UI thread, respectively. If the browser

process becomes congested after t1b, it is possible that t2b >> t1b.

In that case, t2b-t1b >> t2-t1 and, prior to introducing

NextIdleTimeTicks, we might have mistakenly allowed the second input

event to accept the Autofill popup.

NextIdleTimeTicks solved that issue by introducing a new measurement

next_idle, which is the next time the UI thread is idle after showing

the popup. Since the second event is already queued by the time the

popup is shown, the UI thread will not become idle until after the

event is processed. As a result, next_idle > t2b. We then check

whether t2b - next_idle >= threshold.



Since next_idle > t2b, the threshold is not met and the event is

discarded.



However, this still leaves the following loop hole: A user emits

two input events at times t1 and t2, but t2 > t1b (the time

the first input event arrives in the browser and the popup is

shown). In that case, it is possible that next_idle < t2. If the

UI process becomes busy right after next_idle is measure but before

the second input event is emitted, then t2b >> t2 and, in particular,

t2b >> next_idle.



As a result, we might mistakenly let the second event accept the

Autofill popup even if t2 - t1 < threshold.



To address this issue, we adjust when we measure next_idle: We

register the callback for the next time the UI thread becomes idle

only once threshold has passed on the UI thread. Effectively, this

means that we discard all events that were queued in the OS message

queue within the first 500ms after t1b.



Bug: 1475902

Change-Id: Idfb6fffa7bdc03a83fd8612a203919784c01170a

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5246032

Commit-Queue: Jan Keitel

Reviewed-by: Christoph Schwering

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1254048}

entry.title: [infra] Do not exclude PRESUBMIT.py when performing trybot analysis.
entry.content:
Currently, if a change is made to //tools/mb/PRESUBMIT.py it causes all

tests to be run on all try builders because trybot_analyze_config.json

includes an exclusion for "tools/mb/.*" under the chromium config.

PRESUBMIT.py files aren't part of any test targets in chromium so it is

completely unnecessary to run all of those tests. This changes it so

that PRESUBMIT.py files will not be excluded by analyze. This should

cause PRESUBMIT.py-only changes to not run any tests. The existing

ignores regexes were removed since they don't match any existing paths.

entry.title: Use WeakPtr for MoveLoopMouseWatcher::host_.
entry.content:
While MoveLoopMouseWatcher is only created in a single place (i.e., in

HWNDMessageHandler::RunMoveLoop()) and lives for the scope of the

method, HWNDMessageHandler may be destroyed at the end of that method's

scope. When that happens, MoveLoopMouseWatcher's pointer to its host

becomes invalid.



To prevent this from happening, this CL replaces the raw pointer that

MoveLoopMouseWatcher keeps to its host by a weak pointer.



Bug: 1469136

Change-Id: Ia9c5c012a95e18be86251481c8302c6c3b79a73b

entry.title: Shutdown XrHostActivity when browser ends session
entry.content:
Once the XrHostActivity has been created, if the browser process (or

OpenXrDevice code) ends the session (or rejects the session creation),

we can be left in a state where the XrHostActivity is left at the top of

the activity stack.



This change addresses this by calling `finish` on the activity, unless

the shutdown was initiated by it (indicated by it calling new methods to

indicate such). When a shutdown was initiated by it, the activity is

nulled out so that no additional cleanup is done. It is expected that in

these situations the activity will handle disposing of itself.



Bug: 1435548

Change-Id: I6b43c1456b6dfae4e1bb708614eea814a1b06292

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5241674

entry.title: [sync] Allow wallet types to run despite passphrase
entry.content:
Historic background: there was an attempt in https://crbug.com/1413721

to roll out this behavioral change via variations, but it was never

pursued and the code was finally cleaned up in

https://crrev.com/c/4225199, ~four years after deciding against the

behavior in the initial launch, before which the flag was disabled by

default in https://crrev.com/c/1724749.



It isn't clear why AutofillWalletModelTypeController needs to disable

these features for custom passphrase users in transport mode, but the

last patch linked above does say "It was decided not to launch this for

now".



This patch reverts this decision and actually enables those features

for custom passphrase users too, on all platforms (it was already the

case on iOS before this patch because feature

kReplaceSyncPromosWithSignInPromos is enabled).



The affected features include:

1) NON-encryptable types:

syncer::AUTOFILL_WALLET_DATA

syncer::AUTOFILL_WALLET_OFFER

syncer::AUTOFILL_WALLET_USAGE



2) Encryptable types (as per syncer::EncryptableUserTypes()):

syncer::AUTOFILL_WALLET_METADATA

syncer::AUTOFILL_WALLET_CREDENTIAL



The types listed first, with non-encryptable types, don't actually care

if an explicit passphrase is set, and there is no known product

requirement that speaks for excluding those users. With this patch,

those features will activate for users in transport mode with a

custom passphrase set.



As per encryptable types: AUTOFILL_WALLET_CREDENTIAL isn't launched

yet and guarded behind kSyncAutofillWalletCredentialData, hence not a

behavioral change here.



The second one, syncer::AUTOFILL_WALLET_METADATA, is the one remaining

interesting case. In practice it won't run anyway in most cases because

the user cannot have entered the passphrase (there is no UI for it for

transport mode on desktop). Hence, the outcome is that most wallet

datatypes become enabled except AUTOFILL_WALLET_METADATA.



Wallet features don't strictly need AUTOFILL_WALLET_METADATA to provide

a decent user experience, so it seems better than turning off all

functionality.



Change-Id: Ie33d4f3db4b4da270f0d9109506bb4eaacb135c1

Bug: 1429297

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5237366

Commit-Queue: Mikel Astiz

Reviewed-by: Marc Treib

Reviewed-by: Victor Vianna

entry.content:
This change will cause Chrome to render the User Bypass UI in

the Omnibox when a sandboxed top-level page is loaded.



The change also has the network service's instance of

CookieSettings use the sandboxed frame's actual URL to search

for content settings that apply to the frame.



This change does not enable cookies anywhere without an explicit

content setting. This setting could be added with User Bypass or

CookiesAllowedForUrls.



This change will not allow cookies to be accessed in scripts.

The exception only allows HTTP cookies.

entry.title: Fix detection of user scrollability for a node.

Previously AXWeb objects would return as scrollable provided the style

indicated that scrollbars could be drawn. It did not check if scrollbars

where actually rendered or if the either scroll range was non-zero. With

the patch, we now use consistent rules for document nodes. These nodes

require special handling since it is the document's body or html

element that is the scrolling element depending on quirks mode.

entry.content:
The check in ShouldIgnoreForHiddenOrInert() is probably triggered by an

AXMenuList when it is indirectly called by the AXMenuListPopup, before

the AXMenuList has had its cached values updated.



Note that all of the specialized code for AXMenuList* should eventually

go away in favor of an implementation that uses ordinary AXNodeObjects

and AXLayoutObjects from the shadow DOM tree. The specialized classes

are often the source of issues.

entry.title: Use new enum-class style value for UserType.
entry.content:
As for UserType, we are switching from enum to enum-class.

This CL mechanically replaces enum values to enum-class style.

For each type (regular, child, guest, public_account, kiosk_app,

arc_kiosk_app and web_kiosk_app), the following command are run:



git grep -l 'UserType::USER_TYPE_REGULAR' | \

xargs sed -i '' \

-e 's/UserType::USER_TYPE_REGULAR/UserType::kRegular/g'

git grep -l 'user_manager::USER_TYPE_REGULAR' | \

xargs sed -i '' \

-e 's/user_manager::USER_TYPE_REGULAR/user_manager::UserType::kRegular/g'



Then, tools/*, force_installed_metrics.* are excluded manually, because

tools/* are out of scope, force_installed_metrics.* cannot be handled

mechanically due to naming overlap. The force_installed_metrics.* files

will be updated in a following CL.

Also, legacy aliases in user_type.h will be removed in another CL,

as well.



BUG=b:278643115

entry.title: Allow downgrade versions earlier than the bundled version
entry.content:
Component Update supports downgrading of versions in order to support

rollbacks. However, if the component is also bundled, then currently

you can not rollback to a version earlier than the bundled version.

Adding support so that the bundled version is skipped if it has been

seen before and there is a downgrade.



This is done by keeping track of the maximum previous version in the

component updater preferences for the component (as `max_pv`).

In the case of a downgrade (say v2 reverted back to v1), then v2 would

be saved as the previous max, and when selecting which version to use,

the bundled version will only be used if its version is greater than

this saved max. If the bundled version changes to something bigger

(say v3), then it will be used instead of v1.



Bug: 1445973

Test: Manual check plus new unit tests pass

entry.title: Rename {absl => std}::optional in //media/
entry.content:
#cleanup



Automated patch. This is a no-op. Please avoid, as much as possible,

assigning unrelated bugs to this.



Context:

https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/cxx/c/nBD_1LaanTc/m/ghh-ZZhWAwAJ?utm_medium=email



As of https://crrev.com/1204351, absl::optional is now a type alias

for std::optional. We should migrate toward it.



Script:

```

cd media/

function replace {

echo "Replacing $1 by $2"

git grep -l "$1" \

| cut -f1 -d: \

| grep \

-e "\.h" \

-e "\.cc" \

-e "\.mm" \

| sort \

| uniq \

| xargs sed -i "s/$1/$2/g"

}

replace "absl::make_optional" "std::make_optional"

replace "absl::optional" "std::optional"

replace "absl::nullopt" "std::nullopt"

replace "absl::in_place" "std::in_place"

replace "absl::in_place_t" "std::in_place_t"

replace "\"third_party\/abseil-cpp\/absl\/types\/optional.h\"" ""

cd ..



echo "Formatting:"



echo "IncludeBlocks: Regroup" >> ".clang-format"

echo "IncludeIsMainRegex: \"(_(android|apple|chromeos|freebsd|fuchsia|fuzzer|ios|linux|mac|nacl|openbsd|posix|stubs?|win))?(_(unit|browser|perf)?tests?)?$\"" >> ".clang-format"

git cl format

git restore ".clang-format"



git cl format

```



Bug: chromium:1500249

entry.title: Migrate SystemMessageWindowWin to SingletonHwnd
entry.content:
The current implementation of SystemMessageWindowWin creates message-

only windows to listen for events from Windows. This impacts

performance at startup where we have to pay the cost to creating the window to listen. Instead use Singleton HWND in the implementation

of this component to allow sharing a single HWND. We typically see 1-10ms costs for creating an HWND in startup, so sharing the Singleton HWND will lead to modest but measurable startup improvements.

entry.title: [Private Network Access] Disable CORS header checks on pure PNA preflights
entry.content:
Per discussions in [1], we don't really need to do all the CORS header

checks when a preflight is only for PNA and not required for CORS. If

we don't do those checks, we wouldn't need to relax the CORS

safelisted header limit just for PNA preflights before navigation.



This CL introduces a preflight mode, which can be either:

1. kCORS, meaning the preflight is for CORS only.

2. kPNA, meaning the preflight is for PNA only.

3. kCORS | kPNA, meaning the preflight is for both CORS and PNA.



When the CORS bit is not set, we do not send the access control headers

(except Access-Control-Request-Method) and skip the cross-origin header

tests. We keep the Origin header because the site needs this information

to decide whether to allow private network requests.





[1] https://github.com/WICG/private-network-access/issues/116

entry.title: [Soft-Navigations] Remove paint requirements to Emit entry.
entry.content:
This patch continues to track of all Paints which follow an Interaction

which may start a new soft-navigation. If those paints are deemed

attributable to the Interaction (i.e. due to a Dom Modification that was

know task-attributable), only then does that paint "count" towards a

total soft-navigation painted area.



Previously, we would require to see a 2% paint area update (as compared

to some default area, approximately the viewport size).



With this change, we remove that requirement entirely, but leave the

calculation, as it is useful for tracing / logging and may be added to

histogram data.



This patch also cleans up some of the paint tracking logic and fixes a

few small issues where paints could "bleed" across navigations by

accidentally accumulating paint area even after an entry is emitted.

Instead of mistakely accumulating for the *next* soft-nav, we accumulate

a total for the current soft-nav. This helps mark the maximum total

painted area after a soft-nav (i.e. to see what the threshold could

have been).



Future work will want to resolve some of the reasons paints are not

being correctly attributed, and then we may re-enable this requirement.



Bug: 1510706

entry.title: Limit the number of buffered registrations
entry.content:
Buffer up to 80 registration items. When the limit is reached, flush the

buffer to the OS and create a new buffer.



See: go/limits-on-os-registrations for details on the limit.



OBSOLETE_HISTOGRAM[Conversions.OsRegistrationsBufferFlushAfterTimeout]=Replaced by Conversions.OsRegistrationsBufferFlushReason
